section.name: Chapter and Verse
section.description: Parameters that cover varous aspects of formating of chapter and verse layout.

setting.name: Marginal Verses
setting.description: Marginal verses (a.k.a. flying verse numbers) are a specific feature of this macro package. This will place the verse number in the margin area. To use marginal verses set this to True. Default = False
setting.note: At this point marginal verses are limited to two column text.

setting.name: Omit Chapter Number On Single Chapter Book
setting.description: Setting this to True will prevent the chapter number 1 from being displayed single chapter books. Default = True

setting.name: Omit Verse Number One
setting.description: Setting this to True will prevent verse number 1 from being displayed which is normally good for in-line verse formated Bibles that use drop chapter numbers. Default = True

setting.name: Omit All Chapter Numbers
setting.description: Omit all the chapter numbers in the book. (Often this is used for one-chapter books.) Default = False

setting.name: Chapter Verse Separator
setting.description: Change the default c/v separator character or adjust the space by adding some extra code. For example, to kern the space between the separator character you could enter: "\kern.02em:\kern.02em". This setting primary affects the header reference. Default = ":"

setting.name: After Verse Space Factor
setting.description: You may need a little extra space following the verse numbers. This will add space in this context with a factore that is related to the \FontSizeUnit, this way it scales with the text. This can be used with in-line verse layouts. Default = 2

setting.name: After Chapter Space Factor
setting.description: You may need a little extra space following the Chapter numbers. This will add space in this context with a factore that is related to the \FontSizeUnit, this way it scales with the text. This can be used with both in-line and marginal verse layouts. Default = 3

setting.name: Use Adorn Verse Number
setting.description: Set to true to turn on adorn verse numbers.

setting.name: Adorn Verse Number Setting
setting.description: By placing a properly formated setting in this field, TeX will place a verse adornment like parenthesis or anything else you may want to specify. An example for parenthesis would be '(#1)' whereas the #1 is the verse number variable. That must be there for the verse number to appear. If you leave it blank no settings will be output to the settings file. Default = (#1)
setting.note: Not fully tested yet. More work needs to be done on it.

section.name: Columns
section.description: Parameters which have to do with column layout for Scripture publications

setting.name: Title Columns
setting.description: Number of columns used to typeset the main title.

setting.name: Intro Columns
setting.description: Number of columns used to typeset introduction material. Introduction material is defined by USFM markers beginning with \i.

setting.name: Body Columns
setting.description: Number of columns used to typeset the body text.

setting.name: Column Gutter Rule
setting.description: Do you want to place a vertical line between the columns in the column gutter? Default = False

setting.name: Column Gutter Factor
setting.description: Used to set the size of the gutter between columns; this is relative to the font size. Default = 15

setting.name: Two Column Shift
setting.description: Column shift will shift the colums (normally used in two column layout) over n units. This is used with marginal verse format. It will output the \singlecolumnshift command in the TeX settings file. Default = 5

setting.name: Column Gutter Rule Skip
setting.description: It may be necessary to push the top of the gutter rule down a few mm. By setting the number to be greater than zero this will enable you to adjust where the line begins at the top of the page. (Not included in standard ptx2pdf macros). Only enter the number of points, do not add "mm" as That will be added by the system. Default = 0

section.name: Crossreferences
section.description: This section includes all textual elements that go into the Crossreferences area.

setting.name: Include Crossreferences
setting.description: [NOT IMPLEMENTED] Include crossreferences in the output. Defalt = True

setting.name: Crossreference Auto Caller Character
setting.description: Define a character or sequence in this field to enable the use of auto callers in your text. You can even add kerning control as well as in the examples By setting something in this field you will override the autoCallerStartChar setting. A sequence = *,+,¶,§,**,++,¶¶,§§ Use only an asterisk = * Kern an asterisk = \kern0.2em*\kern0.4em Raise an asterisk = \raise .8em\hbox{*} Raise and kern = \raise .8em\hbox{\kern0.2em*} Default = *

setting.name: Auto Callers (Crossrefs)
setting.description: Provide a symbol (or a csv sequence of symbols) is desired for a crossref caller character, rather than the default incremental character(s). Default = \kern0.2em *\kern0.4em

setting.name: Numeric Callers (Crossrefs)
setting.description: Use numeric callers on cross references instead of alphabetic callers.

setting.name: Page Reset Callers (Crossrefs)
setting.description: Restart numbering or character sequence for cross references on each page. Default = False

setting.name: Omit Caller In Crossrefs
setting.description: To omit caller characters from the cross references at the bottom of the page. Default = False

setting.name: Paragraphed Crossrefs
setting.description: Output the crossrefs on the bottom of the page in paragraph format rather than one line for each one. Default = True

section.name: Footnotes
section.description: This section includes all textual elements that go into the footnote area.

setting.name: Auto Callers (Footnotes)
setting.description: Provide a symbol (or a csv sequence of symbols) is desired for a footnote caller character, rather than the default incremental character(s).

setting.name: Numeric Callers (Footnotes)
setting.description: Use numeric callers on footnote references instead of alphabetic callers. Default = False

setting.name: Page Reset Callers (Footnotes)
setting.description: Restart numbering or character sequence for footnotes on each page.

setting.name: Omit Caller In Footnotes
setting.description: To omit caller characters from the footnotes at the bottom of the page.

setting.name: Paragraphed Footnotes
setting.description: Output the footnotes on the bottom of the page in paragraph format rather than one line for each one.

setting.name: Define Footnote Rule
setting.description: Many times a horizontal line is used to separate the main text body from the footnotes. To change the default rule that is generated from the macro, change this setting as necessary. If you do not want a footnote rule, insert a command like \smallskip. This will cause the default horizontal line to not be output. Only a small space will be inserted. The default setting will give you a horizontal line across the text area that is 0.4pt in thickness. Some examples of line definitions would be: \hrule height 0.5pt (slightly thicker moving towards the top of the page) \hrule depth 0.5pt (slightly thicker moving towards the bottom of the page) \hrule height 0.5pt\smallskip (small amount of vertical space before text) \smallskip (no rule will be output) Default = \hrule\smallskip

setting.name: Footnote Rule On
setting.description: If useFootnoteRule in the page settings is set to True, this will set \footnoterule to the setting in defineFootnoteRule.

setting.name: Footnote Rule Off
setting.description: If useFootnoteRule in the page settings is set to False, this will remove any settings from \footnoterule which will remove any footnote rule.

setting.name: Auto Caller Number Characters
setting.description: Number of caller characters to generate before restarting sequence. Default = 26
setting.note: This has not been properly tested. It may not work right.

setting.name: Auto Caller Start Character
setting.description: Unicode value of first character to use for auto-generated callers. This allows the use of vernacular caller letters. It will start at the number specified and continue until the number of characters are reached specified by AutoCallerNumChars. Default = 97 ('a')
setting.note: This has not been properly tested. It may not work right.

section.name: Font Settings
section.description: Information for fonts used in the publication project with this macro package.

setting.name: Font Size Unit
setting.description: Using a value in points (pt), this scales the font size of all elements according to the amount of the value. 1pt is equal to 100%. Example, to decrease the size by 5%, enter the value .095pt. Default = 1pt

setting.name: Line Spacing Factor
setting.description: Scaling factor used to adjust line spacing (leading), relative to font size.

setting.name: Vertical Space Factor
setting.description: Scaling factor used to adjust amount of vertical spaces applied for USFM style sheet SpaceBefore and SpaceAfter values.

setting.name: Header Position
setting.description: Relative position of the baseline of the header to the top edge of the paper (not the text area) Default = 0.5

setting.name: Running Header Rule Position
setting.description: Position of rule under the running head if used. It is measured from the baseline of the header. This is a simple dimension, not a relative "factor". Default = 4mm

setting.name: Footer Position
setting.description: Position of the baseline of the footer relative to the bottom edge of the paper (not the text area). Default = 0.5

Normally we do not want to put any content in the footer as it takes up an extra line which addes up to extra pages in a publication. It is more efficient to put information like page numbers in the running header.

section.name: Hyphenation
section.description: Some information for building TeX commands for building the hyphenation control file and other related files located in the project's hyphenation folder. Some file names are stored in this section. These are not used in the makefile process and can vary depending on how the process is run. Note: remember to re-make/overwrite the current TeX Hyphenation file for the changes to take effect.

setting.name: Create New TeX Hyphen Language Name
setting.description: Create a language name to be used for applying or creating hyphenation rules for text of a specific language. (\newlanguage). This setting is active when useHyphenation is set to True and a value is entered in this field.
setting.note: This arrangement seems to work but it has not been fully tested. It is not clear why the \def statement is needed. This arrangement may not be effective.

setting.name: Set TeX Hyphen Language Name
setting.description: Set a language name to be used for applying or creating hyphenation rules for text of a specific language. (\language=). This setting is dependent on the createHyphenLanguage.
setting.note: This arrangement seems to work but it has not been fully tested. It is not clear why the \def statement is needed. This arrangement may not be effective.

setting.name: TeX Hyphen Character
setting.description: Set the default TeX hyphen character to insert at hyphenation breaks (\defaulthyphenchar). The normal is '‐' (U+2010) but it could be changed to use something like U+200B (ZWSP) Just change the character setting in the value. (Note that normally in the hyphenation word list source text you will find U+002D, a minus sign which also doubles for a hyphen character but it is not a proper one.) Remember to put a '"' (double quote) before the Unicode value, TeX needs this. Default = "2010

setting.name: TeX Hyphenation Penalty
setting.description: The bigger the number the harder it is to break a word in the hyphen list (\hyphenpenalty). This setting is active when useHyphenation is set to True. Default = 0

setting.name: TeX Hyphenation Penalty Off
setting.description: If useHyphenation is set to False, this will automatically set the TeX \hyphenpenalty setting to 10000 which effectivly turns off hyphenation. If useHyphenation is set to True, this setting should be overwritten with the necessary settings to make hyphenation work. (In theory.)

setting.name: TeX Explicit Hyphenation Penalty
setting.description: Like with \hyphenpenalty this will adjust TEX's ability to break explicit hyphens. These are words that occure in the text which are spelled with a hyphen in them. Normally, TeX will not touch these unless this is set to a low number like -50. This setting is active when useHyphenation is set to True. Default = 50

setting.name: TeX Pretolerance
setting.description: Pretolerance is an integer parameter that is used in TeX's line breaking algorithm. Use an integer from -1 to 10000. If \pretolerance is -1, then TeX bypasses the first attempt at breaking a paragraph without hyphenation. Normally it is always best to allow TeX to use its defaults first so the setting here is nothing by default. This setting is active when useHyphenation is set to True. Default = 0

setting.name: Figure Placeholders
setting.description: Turn On Figure Placeholders - If set to true, this macro will not output the actual picture graphic, just the space it goes in. This makes processing much faster. Default = True

setting.name: Chapter Verse Seperator
setting.description: A reference can be included with the illustration and the seperator can be changed with this setting. The default is ":"

setting.name: Path To Illustrations
setting.description: This is the path to the project illustrations collection that TeX will use.
setting.note: This will insert the path dynamically when this setting is referenced.
WARNING: The use of '/' at the end of the picPath will probably cause problems cross-platform.

section.name: Margins
section.description: Here find ye settings that affect margin settings. Arrg!

setting.name: Margin Settings
setting.description: Output margin settings based on the master layout configuration.
setting.note: This will reference the margin unit in the main layout config file

setting.name: Binding Gutter
setting.description: This additional margin space on the binding side (inside) of the page which will enable printing for formats that need more space for binding like with a comb-bind or hole punch. The distance of this setting is determined by additional space added to the inside margin which exceeds the outside margin setting.

setting.name: Extra Right Margin
setting.description: For some single column publications it might be necessary to tweak the right margin to get things to line up, especialy when using marginal verses. This setting is in mm. Enter a number (just a number) which represents the distance in mm that you want to pull the right margin in toward the middle of the page. Defalt = 0mm

section.name: Page Layout
section.description: Page layout information. This covers general page layout format options.

setting.name: Page Height
setting.description: This is the height of the page after it has been printed and trimmed to its final size. Default = 210mm (A5)

setting.name: Page Width
setting.description: This is the width of the page after it has been printed and trimmed to its final size. Default = 148mm (A5)

setting.name: End Book No Eject
setting.description: [NOT IMPLEMENTED] To save space on long publications the next book can start on the same page of the previous one. Default = False

setting.name: Page Border Scale
setting.description: [NOT IMPLEMENTED] Enter in the scale factor for the page border and TeX will scale the PDF file as needed. If you do not enter anything, no scaling will be applied. Here are some examples: scaled 900 = 90% of original size scaled 1100 = 110% of original size (not tested yet) xscaled 800 yscaled 900 (to scale individual directions) width 140mm height 205mm (to scale to a known size) Default = Null (which equates to 1000 or no scaling)

section.name: Text Elements
section.description: General settings for text level elements

setting.name: Quote Kern Amount (Em)
setting.description: Often, when there are quotes within quotes, when they end the two types of quote markers are so close together that, from the reader's perspective, it is hard to tell what is going on. To fix this kerning space is added between the two characters to make it clear which is which. The amount is in em space measurement. For more information on what that is, go to this address: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Em_(typography) Enter the amount in em but do not follow with "em" as the system assumes the measurement is in em. Enter 0 if no kerning of quotes is desired. Defalt = 0.1

section.name: TeX Behavior
section.description: Settings that make TeX behave better

setting.name: Horizontal Fuzz
setting.description: Specify the amount that a horizontal box (hbox) can exceed its natrual size before TeX conciders it to be overfull. The normal Plain TeX default is 0.1pt.

setting.name: Vertical Fuzz
setting.description: Specify the amount that a vertical box (vbox) can exceed its natrual size before TeX conciders it to be overfull. The normal Plain TeX default is 0.1pt.
